issue.title: [BUG] just FYI we see backup lot slower upgrading from 0.14.3-1 to 0.15.1-3
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
hi we saw nearly a doubling of the dump time since upgrading to 0.15.1-3


**To Reproduce**

script do the very same thing and we gone from something like 5min to 8/9min+

2023-10-20 00:00:58 [INFO] - MyDumper backup version: 0.14.3-1
2023-10-20 00:00:58 [INFO] - Started dump at: 2023-10-20 00:00:58
2023-10-20 00:05:57 [INFO] - Finished dump at: 2023-10-20 00:05:57

2023-10-21 00:00:08 [INFO] - MyDumper backup version: 0.14.3-1
2023-10-21 00:00:08 [INFO] - Started dump at: 2023-10-21 00:00:08
2023-10-21 00:04:39 [INFO] - Finished dump at: 2023-10-21 00:04:39

2023-10-22 00:01:09 [INFO] - MyDumper backup version: 0.14.3-1
2023-10-22 00:01:15 [INFO] - Started dump at: 2023-10-22 00:01:15
2023-10-22 00:06:13 [INFO] - Finished dump at: 2023-10-22 00:06:13

2023-10-23 00:00:09 [INFO] - MyDumper backup version: 0.14.3-1
2023-10-23 00:00:09 [INFO] - Started dump at: 2023-10-23 00:00:09
2023-10-23 00:04:40 [INFO] - Finished dump at: 2023-10-23 00:04:40

2023-10-24 00:00:07 [INFO] - MyDumper backup version: 0.14.3-1
2023-10-24 00:00:08 [INFO] - Started dump at: 2023-10-24 00:00:08
2023-10-24 00:04:31 [INFO] - Finished dump at: 2023-10-24 00:04:31

2023-10-25 00:01:02 [INFO] - MyDumper backup version: 0.15.1-3
2023-10-25 00:01:09 [INFO] - Started dump at: 2023-10-25 00:01:09
2023-10-25 00:09:18 [INFO] - Finished dump at: 2023-10-25 00:09:18

2023-10-26 00:01:00 [INFO] - MyDumper backup version: 0.15.1-3
2023-10-26 00:01:00 [INFO] - Started dump at: 2023-10-26 00:01:00
2023-10-26 00:08:20 [INFO] - Finished dump at: 2023-10-26 00:08:20

2023-10-27 00:00:07 [INFO] - MyDumper backup version: 0.15.1-3
2023-10-27 00:00:07 [INFO] - Started dump at: 2023-10-27 00:00:07
2023-10-27 00:07:47 [INFO] - Finished dump at: 2023-10-27 00:07:47



**Expected behavior**
same or better performances ;p
2023-09-30:00:05:13 DUMP temps de dump total : 312 secondes, 5 minutes
2023-10-01:00:06:07 DUMP temps de dump total : 304 secondes, 5 minutes
2023-10-02:00:04:45 DUMP temps de dump total : 283 secondes, 4 minutes
2023-10-03:00:04:25 DUMP temps de dump total : 264 secondes, 4 minutes
2023-10-04:00:04:42 DUMP temps de dump total : 280 secondes, 4 minutes
2023-10-05:00:05:43 DUMP temps de dump total : 292 secondes, 4 minutes
2023-10-06:00:04:41 DUMP temps de dump total : 278 secondes, 4 minutes
2023-10-07:00:04:50 DUMP temps de dump total : 289 secondes, 4 minutes
2023-10-08:00:06:06 DUMP temps de dump total : 302 secondes, 5 minutes
2023-10-09:00:04:36 DUMP temps de dump total : 274 secondes, 4 minutes
2023-10-10:00:04:38 DUMP temps de dump total : 277 secondes, 4 minutes
2023-10-11:00:04:29 DUMP temps de dump total : 267 secondes, 4 minutes
2023-10-12:00:04:43 DUMP temps de dump total : 281 secondes, 4 minutes
2023-10-13:00:04:36 DUMP temps de dump total : 275 secondes, 4 minutes
2023-10-14:00:05:08 DUMP temps de dump total : 306 secondes, 5 minutes
2023-10-15:00:06:17 DUMP temps de dump total : 314 secondes, 5 minutes
2023-10-16:00:04:40 DUMP temps de dump total : 279 secondes, 4 minutes
2023-10-18:00:05:29 DUMP temps de dump total : 328 secondes, 5 minutes
2023-10-19:00:06:06 DUMP temps de dump total : 316 secondes, 5 minutes
2023-10-20:00:05:57 DUMP temps de dump total : 305 secondes, 5 minutes
2023-10-21:00:04:40 DUMP temps de dump total : 279 secondes, 4 minutes
2023-10-22:00:06:15 DUMP temps de dump total : 313 secondes, 5 minutes
2023-10-23:00:04:42 DUMP temps de dump total : 281 secondes, 4 minutes
2023-10-24:00:04:31 DUMP temps de dump total : 270 secondes, 4 minutes
=== upgrade ====
2023-10-25:00:09:19 DUMP temps de dump total : 504 secondes, 8 minutes
2023-10-26:00:08:21 DUMP temps de dump total : 447 secondes, 7 minutes
2023-10-27:00:07:48 DUMP temps de dump total : 467 secondes, 7 minutes


**Environment (please complete the following information):**
Debian GNU/Linux 10 (buster)
MyDumper backup version: 0.15.1-3 vs MyDumper backup version: 0.14.3-1


  just FYI.

best regards,
Ghislain.

There is a know performance issue on v0.15.1. Can you test with the latest prerelease?

issue.title: -- no locks is causing Segmentation fault (core dumped) on centos 9
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
when we try to run mydumper (v0.15.1-1, built against MySQL 8.0.33-25 with SSL support) with -- no locks I am getting Segmentation fault (core dumped) , if i remove -- no locks all seems to go back to normal .

**To Reproduce**
/usr/bin/mydumper --user=--password=--host=--port=--database=r --outputdir= --less-locking --build-empty-files --trx-consistency-only --events --routines --triggers --compress  --logfile=log --verbose=3 --threads=8 --long-query-guard=86400 --no-locks

What mydumper and myloader version has been used?
v0.15.1-1, built against MySQL 8.0.33-25 with SSL support

**Expected behavior**
--no locks should work fine

**Log**


**Backup**


**How to repeat**
use --no locks with mydumper export on centos 9 

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
centos 9
mydumper (v0.15.1-1, built against MySQL 8.0.33-25 with SSL support)

Merge pull request #1330 from mydumper/fix_1299

Check NULL on release_global_lock_function missing

Size : 2.T
Number of files : 1898


I can still able to use mydumper with --no-locks .Its just that when i add --no-Locks I am getting this core segmentation fault

issue.title: [BUG] regarding import of dumps created with --rows and --statement-size
issue.body:
I'm not a 100% sure but at first glance it's my only explanation that there is a bug in mydumper/myloader or at least a possible enhancement:

I have two servers and use mydumper and myloader for cloning databases for development from one to the other.
I create the dumps as following:
mydumper -B "foo" --use-savepoints [...] -t "${MYDUMPER_THREADS}" -r 10000 -s "${TARGET_MAX_ALLOWED_PACKET}" -o "${DUMP_FOLDER}" -x "some regex"

I recently added the -s param to get rid of the warnings.
Our max_allowed_packet size is 67108864 on both systems.

But when I load the dump with myloader I get e.g. this:
`** (myloader:3658304): WARNING **: 09:48:44.988: Thread 10: Error restoring 1: Got a packet bigger than 'max_allowed_packet' bytes
** (myloader:3658304): CRITICAL **: 09:48:44.989: Thread 10: Lost connection error
** (myloader:3658304): CRITICAL **: 09:48:44.989: Error occurs between lines: 306412 and 586760 on file foo.useractions.00000.sql: 
** (myloader:3658304): CRITICAL **: 09:49:07.753: Thread 10: issue restoring foo.useractions.00000.sql: `

So my guess is because the dumps insert multiple rows per INSERT somehow the "statement-size" param isn't checked/used/processes correctly while dumping and a single INSERT containing up to "rows" (= 10000) rows might get bigger than the "max_allowed_packet" size.

Maybe someone familiar with the code/bahaviour could have a look into it?!

Thanks in advance.

comment.body: You are using -r when LOADING whereas I'm using -r when DUMPING.

commits.message:
Merge pull request #1329 from mydumper/enh_1195

Adding --no-schema and fixing checksums

issue.title: Add --no-schema on mydumper and myloader
issue.body:
Currently myloader doesn't accept an option like --no-schema which will ignore the -schema files. That is something that we could implement in future versions as we did with --no-data, which is implemented in mydumper and myloader.

_Originally posted by @davidducos in https://github.com/mydumper/mydumper/discussions/1194#discussioncomment-6343766_

issue.title: [QUESTION] How to apply different conditions for different tables
issue.body:
Hello,
first of all thanks for this tool.
is it possible to set different conditions (`--where`) for different tables?

I have multiple tables where each tables needs a different condition while dumping. Right now I'm doing those tables one by one and basically I'm not using that much of multi thread option of mydumper.

I see a config file but, but unfortunately there's no documents about it and how to use it. I searched in google and didn't find any example too.

Could You please give me an example of how to do it?


Let me give You an example of what I'm doing.

Lets say I have 3 tables in database *mydb* and I want to just dump parts of the data in those tables.

conditions would be like this:
table_a: column_z > 1234
table_b: column_x > 1234
table_c: column_y > 1234


thanks in advance

issue.title: [BUG] regarding import of dumps created with --rows and --statement-size
issue.body:
I'm not a 100% sure but at first glance it's my only explanation that there is a bug in mydumper/myloader or at least a possible enhancement:

I have two servers and use mydumper and myloader for cloning databases for development from one to the other.
I create the dumps as following:
mydumper -B "foo" --use-savepoints [...] -t "${MYDUMPER_THREADS}" -r 10000 -s "${TARGET_MAX_ALLOWED_PACKET}" -o "${DUMP_FOLDER}" -x "some regex"

I recently added the -s param to get rid of the warnings.
Our max_allowed_packet size is 67108864 on both systems.

But when I load the dump with myloader I get e.g. this:
`** (myloader:3658304): WARNING **: 09:48:44.988: Thread 10: Error restoring 1: Got a packet bigger than 'max_allowed_packet' bytes
** (myloader:3658304): CRITICAL **: 09:48:44.989: Thread 10: Lost connection error
** (myloader:3658304): CRITICAL **: 09:48:44.989: Error occurs between lines: 306412 and 586760 on file foo.useractions.00000.sql: 
** (myloader:3658304): CRITICAL **: 09:49:07.753: Thread 10: issue restoring foo.useractions.00000.sql: `

So my guess is because the dumps insert multiple rows per INSERT somehow the "statement-size" param isn't checked/used/processes correctly while dumping and a single INSERT containing up to "rows" (= 10000) rows might get bigger than the "max_allowed_packet" size.

Maybe someone familiar with the code/bahaviour could have a look into it?!

Thanks in advance.

comment.body:
@IZSkiSurfer, then it doesn't make sense, as -s will report if there are rows larger than the `${TARGET_MAX_ALLOWED_PACKET}` and without -r myloader will import the file as it is. 
This are the reproducible test case on a server with max_allowed_packet 67108864 and sbtest table with almost 2M rows total uncompressed dump is higher than 350MB.
Backup with statement size higher than the max_allowed_packet
```
rm -rf data; ./mydumper -o data -v 3 -T sbtest2.sbtest1 -s 77108865
```
The myloader that fails:
```
./myloader -d data/ -v 3 -B sbtest3 -o
```
The myloader that work:
```
./myloader -d data/ -v 3 -B sbtest3 -o -r 1000
```

No. I don't think I've used -r when loading (only while dumping).
But I'll try it as soon as I'll find time..

issue.title: [BUG] mydumper on ARM laptop (osx M1) infinite sleep for AWS aurora DB
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
A clear and concise description of what the bug is.

Infinite wait after schema dumping step (I see only schema files), wait 2 days and nothing happens.

**To Reproduce**
Command executed:
* mydumper with all the parameters

```
   mydumper \
    --host=host.rds.amazonaws.com \
    --user=db_user \
    --password=db_pass \
    --outputdir=/Users/user/dumps/db_name \
    --max-rows=70000 \
    --no-locks  \
    -G -E -R \
    --compress \
    --build-empty-files \
    --threads=4 \
    --compress-protocol \
    --regex '^(db_name\.)'
```
 
* myloader with all the parameters

What mydumper and myloader version has been used?
on ARM:
mydumper v0.15.1-1, built against MySQL 8.0.33 with SSL support
mydumper v0.15.2-1, built against MariaDB 11.0.2 with SSL support
on Intel:
mydumper v0.14.5-2, built against MySQL 8.0.33 with SSL support with GZIP

**Expected behavior**
A clear and concise description of what you expected to happen.
Work as usual as on Intel. I tried the same command and it works, on ARM laptop - not working.

**Log**
If applicable, add the --verbose 3 / -v 3 and --logfile / -L <filename> to the execution of the command and upload the file.
NDA

**Backup**
If applicable, add the list of content of the database path, an `ls -l` will be enough
NDA

**How to repeat**
If applicable, add the minimal table structure and data that we need to reproduce the issue.
Or upload a [core dump](https://github.com/mydumper/mydumper/wiki/Support#core-dump) for cases where mydumper or myloader is crashing.
I not sure that it depends on table structure, as it working fine on Intel laptop and not working on ARM based laptop.

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS version: [e.g. CentOS 7.9, Ubuntu 20.04]
 Intel: MacOS Monterey 12.5.1
 ARM: MacOS Ventura 13.3.1

 - MyDumper version: [ mydumper --version ] - already provided

**Additional context**
Add any other context about the problem here.

mydumper v0.15.2-1, built against MariaDB 11.0.2 with SSL support
on Intel:
mydumper v0.14.5-2, built against MySQL 8.0.33 with SSL support with GZIP

**Expected behavior**
A clear and concise description of what you expected to happen.
Work as usual as on Intel. I tried the same command and it works, on ARM laptop - not working.

**Log**
If applicable, add the --verbose 3 / -v 3 and --logfile / -L <filename> to the execution of the command and upload the file.
NDA

**Backup**
If applicable, add the list of content of the database path, an `ls -l` will be enough
NDA

**How to repeat**
If applicable, add the minimal table structure and data that we need to reproduce the issue.
Or upload a [core dump](https://github.com/mydumper/mydumper/wiki/Support#core-dump) for cases where mydumper or myloader is crashing.
I not sure that it depends on table structure, as it working fine on Intel laptop and not working on ARM based laptop.

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS version: [e.g. CentOS 7.9, Ubuntu 20.04]
 Intel: MacOS Monterey 12.5.1
 ARM: MacOS Ventura 13.3.1

 - MyDumper version: [ mydumper --version ] - already provided

**Additional context**
Add any other context about the problem here.

comment.body: closing for now, reopen when you have some feedback.
